plants.name: Narcissus pseudonarcissus
plants.description: A spring-flowering bulb producing bright yellow trumpet-shaped flowers. Often found in woodlands and meadows, heralding the early spring in temperate climates.
plants.location: Europe, particularly UK and Western Europe
plants.funFact: Wild daffodils have inspired numerous cultural festivals in spring across Europe and are often considered symbols of rebirth and new beginnings.

plants.name: Prunus serrulata
plants.description: Deciduous trees with stunning clusters of pale pink to white flowers that bloom profusely in early spring, celebrated for their spectacular ornamental display.
plants.location: East Asia (Japan, Korea, China) and cultivated worldwide in temperate regions
plants.funFact: The cherry blossom is a national symbol of Japan, celebrated during Hanami festivals where people gather to admire these fleeting blooms.

plants.name: Grevillea robusta
plants.description: An evergreen tree native to eastern Australia with bright orange to red spider-like flowers, blooming in late summer to early autumn but often earlier in warmer regions like Queensland.
plants.location: Australia (Eastern coast, Queensland, New South Wales)
plants.funFact: Despite its common name, the Silky Oak is not a true oak but belongs to the Proteaceae family and is valued for both ornament and timber.

plants.name: Magnolia Ã— soulangeana
plants.description: A hybrid deciduous magnolia tree producing large, fragrant, tulip-shaped flowers ranging from white to deep pink, often one of the first substantial blooms of spring in temperate gardens.
plants.location: Cultivated widely in temperate regions worldwide
plants.funFact: Saucer magnolia flowers often bloom before the leaves emerge, creating a striking floral display that lasts only a few weeks in early spring.
